basics.name: Parham Dibajnia
basics.label: Finance/Accounting Student
basics.summary: I'm Parham, a third year Finance and Accounting Student at the Schulich School of Business

highlights: Analyze applicants' financial status, credit, and property evaluations to determine feasibility of granting loans.
Review loan agreements to ensure that they are complete and compliant in accordance with audit and financial policies.
Originate $3,700,000+ in residential loans per week while co-ordinating with various departments, brokers and lawyers in overseeing the mortgage origination and funding process.
Assessed applicants’ financial standing and credit critically to make informed lending decisions while minimizing losses
Offer products and services to new and existing clients to optimize their banking experience and provide them with financial advice based on their portfolio and situation
Top Legendary Customer Experience score in branch for July and August 2015 with +90% customer satisfaction
Top Sales Goal pace in Branch for Q3 of 2015 (achieved 167% of goal), and continued to exceed all sales goals to date

First-hand learning of the in-depth details of retail banking, including credit rates and terms, administrative branch procedures, and ethical concerns involving banking (money-laundering, fraud, etc )
Directly learned and observed the impact of changing economic markets and interest rates on clients’ day-to-day banking and credit products

volunteer.position: Vibe Music Hit Producer, Spotlight Interviewer and Northern Touch Contributor
highlights: Plan, schedule and present listeners with a diverse urban listening experience over live radio with shows and feature pieces
Communicate and convey insightful ideas to listeners locally and internationally through the production of feature pieces and interviews to be aired to over 300,000 simultaneous listeners

education.institution: Schulich School of Business - York University
education.gpa: 3.7, with A/A+ in Finance, Accounting, Operations Management, Calculus, Economics and Political Science
